Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gilbratar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Moday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at he very convienient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is $22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returnin within 12 months.
In addition to the above weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marsielles
TO THE EAST

The mail steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightlyy, and another for Japan. Passnegers embark at Port Said.

div.head: BARON JENISCH’S DEPARTURE
div.p: The dinner given by II.II the Khedive to Baron Rucker Jenisch on the 10th inst was attended by FI II. Prinoo Mohemed Aly, the Ministers, Ahmad Z«ky Pacha, Da Martino Pacha, Graf von Wedel, Graf von Mobl, Herr von Batow, Dr. Gamprrcht, and the prinoipal members of the Gorman oolony at Cairo.

Baron Rocker Jenisch left Cairo by the 6.15 train on Sunday evening. A large number of friendsofthe popnlar German Dip'omaticAgent bade him farewellatthestation,among them All Bey 8babin (representing II.II. the Khedive), Lord Cromer and the who’e of the Diplomatic and Consnlar Corps, Boatros Pacha Ohsli, Abani Pacha Fakbry Pacha, Mszloum Pacha, Boghos Panha Nubar, Atiz Pacha Izzet, and many others. General regret is felt at the de- partnre of Baron Jenisch. who has proved an admirable representative of his country and whose relations with the Egyptian Government and his fellow-diplomats have been uniformly friendly.

A warm appreciation of Coant Bernstorff, who has been appointed to aacoaed Baron Ruoker-Jenisob, appears in the “Standard.” "It ia hardly neoe«S'ry,” the journal remarks, to state that Connt Bernstorff arrived in Eng Und at a time when, for various reasons, the feelings of Germany and England towards one another were of a far from friendly nature. As first Secretary of the German Embassy, be has always set before himself the task of altering those feelings by every mean* in his power, afoce he is fi'tnly convinced that hostility, whesther open or covert, can only be dinaatrons even bh conn tries.

Sir Malcolm McIlwraith was receivd in audience by his Highness on Saturday, when he submitted his report on the Egyptian Tribunals for 1905.

div.head: CAIRO LAW STUDENTS
div.p: We understand that calmer feelingi now prevail among the Law 8obool students, whose recent attempt at an nltimatom has been raverely criticised by several of our Cairo contemporaries. The “Journal du Caire" re. marks : * Before claiming the fulfilment of their demand* the students rf *he Law School should have thomrht of their comrades of the Polyteobnio end the 8chool of Agriculture, who stood by them only tro firmly, and remembered that their colleagues had suffered and suffered, heavily. throoRh their oonduot and while they were perm tted to rstom to their olasses their allies were expelled.”

After disavowing the strike and offering their submission the threat «*f another strike made by the law students was stupid and treacherous : it may prove to have postponed the alteration of the regulations in favonr of contain of their demands, and it i» hardly likely to inspire the educational authorities with great oonfidenoe in their good faith

div.head: THE SUCRERIES
div.p: Effect of Judgement
PETITION FROM NAG HAMADI

The Paris correspondent of a financial con­temporary states that the declaration of the bankruptcy of the Egyptian Sugar Refineries will probably involvo the banks and those who have discounted the Crouier bills in heavy losses. Only a few days ago the Austrian Litn- derbank stated in its annual ba’anc»-*beet that the Paris branoh had in its portfolio G.OOO.OOOf. worth of these bills. At the Conoordat arrange­ment the Lnuderbank received in cash 20 per oent., and 80 per oent. in preference shares of the Egyptian Sugar Refineries. Nevertheless, the direutors thought it advisable to write off l,500,000f. for all eventualities. This, reserve will, of ooorse, be ineoffioient to oover the actual losses ihonld the failure be confirmed in the Coart of Appeal.

The judgment of the Mixed Conrt at Cairo has caused intense dismay in Upper Egypt, and it may be safely said that no judgment of the Appeal Court baa been awaited with more extreme anxiety than its forthcoming decision on Wednesday nexL As a sample of native feeling on the matter we give the following translation ot a telegram seat to the President of the Mixed Appeal Court at ALexandria and signed by 72 native farmers. and sugar planters of Nag-Hamadi :— 1

Wo, the undersigned, husbandmen of Nag- ifomadi, humbly anbmit to yon onr petition and crave of yon, in virtue of yonr love of jastioe and yoor conscience, to quash the judgment of the Court of 1st Instance in the matter of |the Suceries and to accept the arrangement proposed by the company. The company which buys coniderable stocks of sugar cane from us, is the mainstay of our welfare, and the judges of the our children and our kinsfold the continuance.

company has heretold sugar plantations is pray of you for the sake of and evr since we grant us this privelege by giving judgement in accordance with the dictates of compassionate equity and earnestly hope that you will not be the instrument whereby the income from over foar thousand feddans of land, which is the mainstay of our livelihood, will be lost to us for ever."

div.p: Besides the control of the Peyoom Light Railway the objects ol the Anglo-Belgien Company of Egypt are to oarry on financial, railway, tramway, eleotrio, building, land deve­lopment, industrial, and shipping bosiness in Egypt and the 8udan, and the directors will give their attention to tbe question of the navigation of the Nile, especially in the Delta. Among Baron George de Rentet’s olleagues on the board will be a director of the Afrioan Banking Corporation and a director of the AnglthEgyptian Back. div.p: An unsatisfactory Sentence
(Prom our Correspomdeht).
Port 8aid, Monday.

Tho Native Conrt here has sentenced a Berberin, who recsntly attaoked and severely injured Chevalier F. Suivioobfl, of the Italian Consulate, to one year’s imprisonment with bard labour. Tho sentence has prodaoed an unfavourable impression in tome quarters, as it is not thought the punishment fits the crime, considering the serious nature of the ipjariee inflated on the vi tim.
Port Said Salt.
The British steamer E Idie reoently left, with a oargo of 3,700 tons of Port Said salt, for Calontta.
Explosives.

Altogether four steamers carrying explosives arrived within a few days. The 8.3. Viotoriooa bad 200 tons of oordite for Hong Kong, an Italian steamer, the Manin, carried 75 tons of explosives for Calontta. and the S S. Wilgunde and 83. Lowthsr Castle oarried 50 tons and 140 tons of explosive matter, respectively— a very respectable quantity, considering how far a little of this matieral will go.
U.S. Transports

The United States transports MacClellen and Kilpatrick arrived here on Saturday morning. carrying together over 1,000 officers and man. The e troops art bound for the Philippine Islands, but will probably be here some days as certain repairs have to be execated to the boilers of one of the transports.
Sport.

There wu a Rugby matoh on 8atnrday afternoon between Port Sail and H.M.9. Minerva It was a one sided affair all through and the Minerva won by 14 points to nil. The result is not discreditable to Port Said, aa they were unfortunate in not being able to pot a foil team on the field. However, tbe objeot in view wu attained, Damely, to have good exercise and an enjoyable afternoon’s sport

div.p: We understand that there is no foundation for the report emanating from the “Sndan Times” that several soldiers had attacked their officers at one of the Bahr el Ghaetl stations. EGYPTIAN COMPANY PROMOTING

To the Editor of the Eoitptiam Gazette Dear 8ir,—la view of the great aotivity now prevailing in fhe local shtre market and the number of new flotations, I think that it may not be unadvi*ab!e to draw attention to ths warnings against wild oat schemes on which both Lord Cromer and Sir Vinoent Corbett have animadverted. These words of w«rning were angrily protested against by the oompany- mongers a* being oaloulatel to prevent the influx of Baropotn capital into Egypt hot the oompany mongers, will only have themselves to thank for this if they continue to repeat some of the marcruvres which have been so soosewfally practised lately. A oompany reoently was laonched with a moderate oapital, of which nearly forty per oent was absorbed by the prosooters and vendord for the good will of tbe business, the annual profit of which waa probably prudently not revealed. Taking the highest price touched by the shares, the value of the company wonld appear to have increased threefold since the flotation, is this inorease dae to the genuine belief of the investing pabtio in the bona-fide* of the oonoern or merely to skilfal manipulation on the part of some estate individuals! Unfortunately there are rnnoora afloat as to the extra ordinarily di*iutere*ted endetvoor* of a few of the gentlemoi oonoerned to pot their friends on “a good thing.” Nnmsroos are the oom- plaints of lackless applicant* for shares, who. thoroughly relyisg on the verbal promises of some of the direotors, sold a portion of the allotment only to find oat the worthle*sness of directorial prealfotment promises by being radely awakened to the faot that instead of selling one half of th*ir allotment they had sold from twioe t» five times the smoont.

The natural result is that, having oversold their allotment th*y have bad to oover at a very oonriderable loss. It may be said that it was impossible to give eflect to the promise* that were given, but why in such a case did tk> directort not elegy ths application4 list until the lait mommkd rath. Bat oonsiHer tbi BTeot me**gards the operations of the oornering qoinicat*. In vain the snare of the fowler was spread in sight of the bird. The e astote operators were not foolish enoogh to thow their band bat allowed a gulled public to believe that the great rnsb for the rhsres had exhausted itself, and that they might con­fidently teokon on obtaining something like ten per oent. of their application, to which extent they probably sold, and in so doiog they delivered themselves into the hands of the promoters of the corner1. I enclose my oard, which you are at liberty Jto place at the disposal of the directors, and rpmain.—Yoors truly, ^“VioiLAjre."
Alexandria, March 10. f
P.S — In joatioe to some of the direotor* I thoold like to point ont that they are not all professional financiers.

The Bishop of Hereford has arrived in Eag land from Egypt. Daring his stay in Egypt and the Sudan hi* lordship seems to have beeu much interested in the native character. In a letter he wrote home to his diocese he express­ed the opinion that Christian people can learn practical lessons as to prayer and sobriety from Mohsmedan*. The universal prayer of on* sixth of the human rsoe at the summons of the meozzin and their geojral abotinenoe from strong drink have deeply imprewed him. “It is a shame.” he say*, “to ns aa a Christian people, if we remain behind the Mohamedans in temperanoe, sobriety, and self control."

div.head: TO-DAYS TELEGRAMS
div.p: LA COURRIERES DISASTER.
GOVERSMBMT RELIEF.
NUMBER OF VICTIMS: 1,150-
Paris, Maroh 12.

The Chamber has unanimously voted 500,000 fcs. for the relief of the families of the miners of La Courri^res. The roll-call shows that the viotims number 1,150. Only 90 bodies have baen recovered. Farther operations have been stopped owing to accumulations of fire damp and the stench emanating from the bodies. There are various theories regarding the canse of the disaster. It is generally believed that fire-damp accumulated and came in contact with the naked lights which are always used in the Courri&res mines, where fire-damp h is hitherto been unknown.(Reuter.)

The Chamber of Deputies passed a vote of oondolenoe for the Leas viotims and a grant of 506,000 francs.

GORDON CHALLENGE POLO CUP.

By the defeat of the 60th on Wednesday three teams tied with the same number o’ points for the honour of oontesting the final with the Tourists. As the manoeuvres com­menced yesterday, there was no time to play off the ties, consequently the Tourists beoome holders of the cup, and rightly eo, as they have come through the tournament without defeat. To fill up the afternoon a matoh was played between the Tourists and a Cairo team, tho latter proving victorious. After the game Mrs. Bullock presented the oup to the winners and in addition a small souvenir to eaoh member of the team. Capt. Bayley, in a few words, thanked Col. Gordon, in the name of the members of the Polo Clab, for the very handsome onp he had presented to them.

The tournament has been a great snooeas and some quite good polo has been seen during the fortnight, and if in fature the teams are selected earlier in the season and have more practice together, we shall see a great improvement in the polo in Cairo.
KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB.
A Skye Meeting will be held at Ghezireh on Wednesday, the 58th inst.
INTERNATIONAL DONKEY DERBY.

The International Donkey Derby took plaoe on Sunday night at 11.30 p.m., when the noon was at its fullest. This annual event is quite a popular meeting insomuch that the j Dokeys are the waiters from the varions Cairo hot^s, and their steeds are the ordinary donkeys used for riding pnrposss in the neighbourhood. Natu­rally there is a great gathering of the friends of the riders and of the native population, and some difficulty in keeping the course round Ghezireh clear of eager partizanp. The prizes raDge from £5 downward and there were fourteen entries (or the first race, which was won in great s‘yle by Mr. Hans Leek, of the Hotel du Nil, who kept ahead all the way and passed the winning post with some three lengths in his favonr. The coarse measures about three miles and was covered by the winner in seven minates. The seoond race, which was a distance of one mile with prizes of P.T. 250, 125, and 75, was wjn by Mr. Koeffler, of Shepheard’s staff

div.head: THE FUTURE OF THE SUEZ CANAL
div.p: THE QUESTION OF REFORMS.
A FORMER DIRECTOR’S VIEW.

The Japanese Ambassador, Viscount Hayashi, G.C.V.O., was the guest of tha Newcastle and Gateshead Chamber of Commerce at the annual dinner, recently, the President Sir Charles Nark Palmer, M.P., being supported by a num­ber of captains of tho Japanese Army, Lord Edmond Fitzmanrice, Uuder-Seoretary for For eign Affairs, the Eirl of Durhan, the Mayors of Newcastle and Gateshead, and Justices Bigham and Walton.

Sir Charles Palmer, who is a former director of the Saez Canal, in proposing the toast of ‘ The Japanese Empire,” remarked that we were looking forward to an extension of our trade in the East,and to the time when it would be necessary for steamers of more power and greater dimensions to pass through the Saez Caoal. They had beeu startle 1 daring the past few weeks by the faot that the course was blooked owing to an aooident to a cargo stea­mer which should not have ooonrred.What was wanted was the establishment of a large water­way, and a considerable reinotion of dues. (Applause.) As a former director of the 8nez Canal, hi balievad the directors would be pre­pared to oarry out necessary reforms. Not only was a bigger waterway needed, but it should be more under the control of the countries that had the greatest interest in it. (Hear, hear.) He hoped Vi'OOunt Hayashi would assist ns wi^h the powerfal aid of his great nation in bringing abont the reform th.vt ho had suggested. (Applause.)

Lord Fitzmaurice, rep'ying to the toast of the "Honse3 of Parliament,” also allnded to the Suez Caual. The Forfi'n Office hid, he said, recently aotei promptly in regard to a danger which arose on the E astern side of the Saez Canal, where they had some reason to question the legitimacy of the appearance of a considerable force of Tarkich troops at a point wh ch the Foreign Offi ^e considered was Egyp tian erritory. The Foreign Offioe were deter­mined to make the frontier of Egypt on t hit side absolutely secure against dinger, and they had asserted the rights of the Government of Egypt. (Cheers.)

div.head: PARADISE FOR PIGMIES
div.p: A movement, which has the support of Mr. Chamberlain, Lady Stanley (w‘d-w of the well- koown explorer), Sir H. If. Johnston, the Earl and Connte83 of Orford, the Earl and Coantess of Romney, Lord and Lady Wenlook, Lord and Lady Belper, and others, is on foot for the pur­pose of sending an indap9ndeut industrial mission to tha Congo Forest, whither the pigmies, who visited Cairo last year and afterwards went to England, will return later in the year. The proposal, which has the ap­proval of tha Belgian Government, is to estab­lish two or three villages in healthy parts of th:s dense forest, when the pigmies might be indnoed to reside and be taught how to oultivafo rioe, totatoes, bananas, and tobaoco.

div.head: THE ARTESAN BORING AND PROSPECTING COMPANY
NILE VALLEY CO.

p.hi: A MRS DEI) RECONSTRUCTION SCHEME APPROVED.

div.p: An .extraordinary general meeting of the Nile Valley Company, Ltd., wax held on March 5th at Winchester House, Old Broad- street, London, EC., Mr. R. J. Price, M. P.,
presiding.

The Chairman said the new scheme ot le’onstrootion wis prsoncally the old scheme m'h one addition—that was to say, section 1 til of the Companies A’fc was row included. The shareholders knew that that was the dissentient shareholders' clansn in the Com­panies Act. As they were aware by the circular, aninjanotion was obtained against the directors oontinning the old scheme. He was sorry that th*ir good intentions had resulted in the shareholders being troubled to attend an n'ra meeting. If it bad not been for the injunction they would have been holding the confirmatory meeting that day, and should have be-in able to settle their bnsinos* more promptly. It was a misfortune, he thought, for the company but still it oonki not be helped. With regard to the progress at the mine, hi wn gl*d to say that it vis really opening op very we’l at depth. The lowest part of »hs mine now i.howeigood results. They were reached in the wints from the lower level, which was now down 102 ft, or 801 ft from the tnrface, and from a point 2 ft below the seccnd level, or 22ft from the sorfise, the assays had been extraordinarily good. The vinzs had followed the reef. Ie maintained a width of abont SO ins, and was even wider than that in a good many p'acea, while the vetoes were distinctly goo i. At 91ft the reef was 28 ins wide ; the north face was worth 26.1 dwts. At 95ft the reef was 85 ins wide ; on the north faoe it was worth 8.4 dwts and on the sooth face 81.2 dwts At 91ft the reef was 29 ins wide ; on the north face it wm worth 42 dwtt. and on ’he sonth f-ioe 43.2 dwts. At 102.t the reef was 29 ins wide ; on the north fan it was worth 8 5 dwts and on the sooth face 20 dwt*. Those were extraordinarily good values, and it looked as if the direitor*' prognostioa'ioo woild be fulfilled, that the orliuary working of tbs mine wmld pay tin expenses. Of coarse, any quantity of stnff of those values woeld very mnch more than pay the expense*, but it looked aa if they ought really to pay thsir expenses right along, an 1 when they got good staff make profits. That they would get good staff in other parts of the mine personally he had no doabt The fnt that the raef was going dowa as it was showsd that U»u’» geunine fissnre, and it looked as • th® va'uee would go down These, as *A*nxy were, of *«>«, better than they bad in the upper portion of the mi ie, and if they found in addition the rich patches they hope! for,! notwithstanding the expensive nature of m:ning in Egypt, they ought to do very well At all events he thought the shareholders wonld feel that with asrays like ihose in the lowest por­tion of the mine, it would be the height of folly mt to raise more money and go on. (Hear, hear ) Of oonrse, there might he differ­ences of opinion as to whether they ware rais­ing the money in the best w-y ; but ho thought men of business wonld reali e tint they wore raising it in the only pr*ct o »ble way. One shareholder had suggested deben­tures. IIs (the Chairman) bad tried that before and he knew p»ople would not take debentures. Another gentleman bad written siiggeaM"g preference shares. The soma remark app'ied to that Pra dicaUy roc instruction was the O’.ly method, and be was sorry that, owing to the enmbroas nature nf our company law, reoon- ■traotion was soch a troob’e-o no. wearisome, and expan-ive business The Chvrmtn con­cluded by moving tho three reconstruction resolutions.
Colonel Spragge seconded the motion.
The solicitor explained the provisions of the agreement, and the resolutions were carried by the requisite majority, one shareholder only dis«entiag in the case of the third resolat on.

Mr. Wdeman proposed a vote of thanks to the Chairman, and suggested that the share holders should plaoe ou record their opinion that they most deeply deplored the iH advi-ed action of the gentleman who took steps to vitiate the reconstruction proceedings which were previously approved and passed. That gentleman had gratuitously invo’vei tb a oom- pany in a vary great additional exnoise. vr'jioh had fallen upon the shareholders in one w.yor another Shareholders should reogoire, b fore ^they took saoh steps as had been taken by a li.lder of twenty shares, some responsibility n it only to them*elve«, but to their fellow shareholders.

Mr. Bn-good seconded the motion, and art the ssme time poiated out that there could not bo any lost to the shareholders from the action which had been referred to because the direo tors, having bad tbs scheme dec’ared ultra vires, would no donbt have pleasure in paying the ooststhemselves. (Laughter.)
The Chairman remarked that he was not at all convinoed that the scheme was oltra vires.
The motion was ad -p’.ed, and the proceedings then terminated.

div.head: EGYPTIAN IN SINAL
div.p: Prof. Flinders Petrie gavo the fourth of bis lectures at the Continental Hotel, Cairo, yesterday sfernoon. The subject was the exploration of the antiquities of Sinai by i Prof. Petrio’s party Lst winter. Views wore frhewn of the bi*torio road down to 8inai, and the water of E!;m. The party first s'ayod at tho mines of Wady Maghareh, which were a source of turquoise frern ihotimoof the first dynasty. Par above the mines is a carver! relief ot Ssmorkhet, a king of the 1st dynasty, conquering ths Bjdawy chief; this is the oldest sculptured scene on a W,re soa'e that is known. The modern miners bad onhappily destroyel more thm half of the long series of later inscriptions, and those that were If P have been nearly all removed fr safety to the Cairo Museum.

From hero the prrty wont to the mines and temple ofSerabit el Khadon, about twenty miles to the north. This temple is on a plateau of ssnd«tone, which falls away in precipices eight hundred feet high, and is cut through by deep gorges. Oq approaching ibetemp'e many shelters of stones are soon, some with religious tablets 6et up in them, Theso appear to have been nsed by th)*>e who came to bleep by the temple in order to obtain oracular dreams. 3uch stones are the parallel to the Bethel stone of Jaoob’s dream.

The original temp’o was only a rock-cave, with altars plaoed in it, and a row of memorial atones set np in front of it. Th;s was first started ai early as Saueferu at the close of the third dynasty, and w.ia much enlarged in the twalf.h dynasty before 3.000 B.c. On the hdl io frout of the temple burnt i-acrifices were fcontinually offered, so that a great mass of ashes was accumulated of which about fifty tons yet remain under later building'. Subsequent ly, in 'he eighteenth and nineteenth dynasties tho temp'e was greatly extended, until it was »Ver two hundred feet in length.

The largest chambers in the temple were for courts of ablutions, with a tank in the ! middle and pillion plaoed arnnnd it. This ia the proto'yps of the hanafiyek oourt of the Moslem mosqn*. It »h*w* the great importance attached to a ritual of oeremonial ablations, as also watrthe oase in the Jewish system. Many small altars for bnrnirg incense upon were also in the sacred cave.
The worship here was of Hat-bor, who was the Egyptian form fir many fire'gn goddesses, especially for the oow goddess Ath-thor or A’-Ui-Kiati u. whose name is supposed to

be the origin of that „f Kat hot The —'♦5«0' Semitio charao’er of the worship ot Serabit shews that it was probably a native shrine of Ashtar originally. The burnt sacrifice!, the incense altar*, the oourts of ablutions, and the shelters for dreamers are all Semitio and not Egyptian neage*. Great quantiser of vari ins offerings of gUted pottery ware found in the shrine, but all had been broken.

Tho mines of Serabit ware also examined, the mode of working was atndiod. a >d the toils were fmnd. The records of the mining expedi­tions form the most important part of the tamole insariprio os. They show that large bodies of some fire hundred men wore sent f r two or three months at a time. These meo were minotely organised with many grades, and duans of different officials emp’nyod to atten t to every detail of the work The sup­plies we e brought up by a service of biiats on the Re 1 S-a and a trein of fiv-* h r-dred a-ses to carry both f«'d and wu'sr. Th s whole ofthede’ad' w>»k out in a fi ring manner whnu studied.

A very important resnlt wss the finding of a n*-w kiuil nf writing, apparently Semitio and perhaps proto Phco roian, dating about 1500 B.C This decisively shews that Israelites too may probably have had a writing of their own at the time of the Exodus.

The examina'ion of the condition of the antiquities, the evidences of ancient water snpp y and vegetation, and the distances to whi h the Egyptians took ore to obtain fuel for smelting, all shew hat the climate was the 1 same anciently aa at present There cannot , therefore have been mure than about five thousand persons iu tba Peninsula, and the Israelites canno* have numbered more It is ' suggested by Prof Petrie that the original j census lists wire both of tints and person* ;
| and the word lor a family being the same a* for a thousand the numbers of tents became ■ mis inderstood as thousands in la'er times, and so originated the exaggeration of uombers.
A bri*f aoc mot of the discovery this winter ! of the site of the Jewish temple of Onias was | alre given by Prof. Po’rie, and we hope to i-soe a ful'er account of this to m rrow.

p.note:
EXPEIUMRNTAL FARMS.
The experimental farm? which the Govern­ment has estab'ished in this oonntry, says the "3adan Times," have in their way done much that is valuable in the agricultural develop ment of the Sudan. AHhongh few know exactly what there (arms are doingowing to the mystery in whioh their progress has been shrouded so fa* yot those who visit them speak highly of the results obtained at them and considor them as a practical and free school for the eduo&tion of the natives.
It is time, however, that the experimental farms and especially the central farm took a step forward. The great prob'em of agricultoral labour should be tackled and the day is not far off when the ooutitry will bs confronted with it
A* the Sudan is eipected to be one of the world's grain-produoing countries it is advis­able to commence some experiments on how to supplement ths bruited labour supply that is available in it Now that the long expeoted Red Sea Railway is open, and the prioe of foel has boon vastly reduced, the hour is propitious to experiment on the nse of steam machinery for ploughing, lowing and threshing. By oamparing the cost ot work done by machinery with the same when done by manual labour it should not bs diffnnlt to determine the obeaper mean*. That the wages of agricultural labourers will rise is foreseen by all. This rise will certainly prove detrimental to the interests of the country for then the cost of raising its cotton and cereals will increase, thus making it doubly diffhnlt fir the Sudan to oompete with other oonntrie* io placing its products on the markets of the world.
We appreciate the difficulties which stand iu the way of realising the above. A large sum of money will have to be foand in order to meet the initial expenses, in addi­tion to a handiome yearly allowance for the upkeep of the machinery. Bat the results will surely justify any outlay. If favourable— and we belie re they will bi so—people will not be deterred from cultivating large areas of land by the toir of not being able to raise sufficient labour The strfiu on the now limited resour­ces of labour in the oonntry will be re'ieved. and thousands of acres will be placed under cultivation.
